title.narrative: MRC-FAPESP: New approaches to the treatment of Paracoccidioidomycosis

description.narrative: Humans have evolved complex and effective ways of fighting infections caused by microbes such as bacteria, parasites, fungi and viruses, the immune system. Sometimes the immune system goes wrong and this can cause serious diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and diabetes. Our research aims to understand at a molecular level how the cells of the immune system are able to recognise different microbes and the ways in which these cells respond to cause the familiar symptoms of an infection such as fever and tiredness, and to generate specific antibodies that fight the invading microbes. In this project we will study the way in which immune system cells are activated by sugar-binding proteins associated pathogenic yeasts and plants, in particular the way they bind and activate the Toll-like receptors of the innate immune system. Understanding the molecular basis for interactions between these pathogens and immune cells will allow us to carry out a screen to identify new candidate drugs that might be effective therapies for these important diseases.

The over-arching objective of this project is to define the molecular mechanisms by which plant and pathogen lectins interact with the innate immune system. We will exploit this information to screen for new small drug molecules which can potentially be used as therapy in paracoccidioidomycosis. Aim 1: Determination of the molecular basis of immune modulation by the plant lectin Artin M (1) Charcaterization and quantification of the interaction between Artin M and TLR2, in particular the TLR2 N-linked glycans using biophysical techniques (surface plasmon resonance, isothermal titration calorimetry,. (2) Elucidation of the structure of the Artin M/ TLR2 complex using X-ray crystallography and cryo electron microscopy (3) Characterisation of the activated heterodimeric conformations of TLR2, TLR1 and TLR6 induced by Artin M binding using analytical ultracentrifugation and structural analysis Aim 2: Determination of the structure of the lectin paracoccin from the pathogenic yeast Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, the causative agent of paracoccidioidomycosis, the most prevalent systemic mycosis in Latin America. Active E. coli produced protein will be used for crystallisation and structure determination. Paracoccin is an agonist for TLR2, specifically requiring the 4th N-glycan of TLR2, and also activated TLR4. We will elucidate the activation mechanism at the biophysical and structural level using the experimental approaches outlined in Aim 1. Aim 3: We will set up and validate in silico and medium through put screens to identify small molecule antagonists of immunomodulation mediated by the lectin proteins described. Using experience gained screening for antagonists and agonists of TLR4 we will identify non-competitive inhibitors and activators of TLR2, the target of immune modulation mediated by Artin M and paracoccin.
